result.text:
the reason cursor and windsurf released models optimized for speed is because it's way more doable than building an intelligence-pushing foundational model

1. take qwen3 and fine tune it via RL on your harness
2. slap it on Cerebras (or optimized GPU) hardware
3. let that medium-smart, super-fast model cook

for coding agent companies, if you want to bring something of value to market, building a new foundational model is orders of magnitude harder than fine-tuning an open model and optimizing inference.

frankly, it's the efficient way to release something that approaches the pareto frontier and I like that coding agent companies are starting to participate. 

but don't mistake this for coding agents companies declaring "medium smart but fast > highly smart but slow"

result.text:
Every marketing leader I talk to is facing the same challenge:¬†Scale üì∂

The demand for content has exploded, but the systems behind it haven‚Äôt kept up. Teams are expected to launch more campaigns, in more markets, with more data, all while maintaining brand integrity and speed.

Chat-based AI tools help individuals move faster. But they don‚Äôt solve the harder problem:¬†scaling content creation across markets and audiences.

Over the past year, we‚Äôve seen the limits of chat-based AI inside large organizations.

üì¢ Today, we‚Äôre introducing ‚äû Jasper Grid ‚äû ‚Äî the backbone of Content Pipelines.

‚äû Grid is a unified, no-code system that lets AI agents plan, produce, and optimize content at scale. It transforms structured inputs like briefs, data, and brand guidelines into launch-ready assets with speed and precision.

Under the hood, Grid runs on a network of modular AI agents, a resilient scheduler, and deep integrations with the tools marketers already use ‚Äî all governed by brand guardrails so teams can move fast¬†without losing control.

üèÜ The result: faster time to market, consistent brand execution, and true operational scale.

AI is becoming infrastructure.¬†The next generation of enterprise marketing will run on systems built for speed, precision, and trust.

Proud of the @heyjasperai team and our early customers who helped shape this moment.

result.text:
I apologize for the recent postings that are rife with political commentary, but I felt compelled to finally speak up about what I believe is an imminent threat to the core values of the United States and our belief systems.

The policies of unfettered illegal immigration have proven to be a disaster across the globe. Australia, Canada and Western Europe are all feeling the consequences of poor policy decisions.

These policies have resulted in stagnating economies and de minimis growth in GDP per capita, since the majority of illegal immigrants are provided housing, benefits, and hiring advantages at the expense of tax-paying citizens. This is a massive tax on the lower and middle class citizens.  

As a result, affordability has risen and violent crime has soared.  This has been a massive tax on societies with negative outcomes.

Furthermore, the scourge of anti-semitism, the rise in political violence from the extreme Left (assassinations), and the misinformed support of radical Islamists needs to be met with facts about what this approach has cost so many other Western Nations that are further down the road with this failed experiment. 

Their citizens have quite literally paid with blood and money as a result of suicidal empathy.  

We need to heed this experience.  Policy matters.  Decisions have consequences.  Choose wisely

result.text:
I've been waiting to go public on this until I was sure; but, I am officially coming out of retirement into the coaching space for Apex Legends.

I'm only interesting in serious offers, with committed PL/CC teams and orgs. I have plenty of experience coaching Apex, both individually (over 100 players to date) and with teams (16 to date). I have a roughly 95% success rate with everyone I coach, seeing a 20-30% increase in overall scrim/CC performance per player over the first 3 months.

If interested, feel free to DM, and we can get into the specifics, and see if we blend!

Êò®Â§©Êàë‰ª¨ÂºÄ‰∫Ü‰∏™Áõ¥Êí≠„ÄÇÊ≤°ÁúãÁöÑÊúãÂèãÔºåËøôÂÑøÊòØ‚ÄúÊáí‰∫∫ÂåÖ‚ÄùÔºö

Êàë‰ª¨ÂÆö‰∏ã‰∫Ü‰∏ÄÁªÑÂÜÖÈÉ®ÁõÆÊ†áÔºöÂà∞ 2026 Âπ¥ 9 ÊúàÔºåÊàë‰ª¨Ë¶ÅÊêûÂá∫‰∏Ä‰∏™‚ÄúAI ÁßëÁ†îÂÆû‰π†Áîü‚ÄùÔºåÂÆÉÂæóËÉΩÂú®Âá†ÂçÅ‰∏áÂùó GPU ‰∏äË∑ëËµ∑Êù•ÔºõÂà∞ 2028 Âπ¥ 3 ÊúàÔºåÊàë‰ª¨Ë¶ÅÊêûÂá∫‰∏Ä‰∏™ÁúüÊ≠£ÁöÑ‚ÄúËá™Âä®Âåñ AI Á†îÁ©∂Âëò‚Äù„ÄÇ

Êàë‰ª¨ÂæàÂèØËÉΩÂÆûÁé∞‰∏ç‰∫ÜËøô‰∏™ÁõÆÊ†áÔºå‰ΩÜÊàë‰ª¨ËøòÊòØÂæóËØ¥Âá∫Êù•„ÄÇ‰∏∫Âï•Âë¢ÔºüÂõ†‰∏∫Ëøô‰∫ãÂÑøÔºàÂ¶ÇÊûúÂÅöÊàê‰∫ÜÔºâÂΩ±ÂìçÂÆûÂú®Â§™Â§ß‰∫ÜÔºåÊàë‰ª¨ËßâÂæóÊú¨ÁùÄÂØπÂÖ¨‰ºóË¥üË¥£ÁöÑÊÄÅÂ∫¶ÔºåÂøÖÈ°ª‰øùÊåÅÈÄèÊòé„ÄÇ

‰∏∫‰∫Ü‰øùËØÅAI‰∏ç‚ÄúË∑ëÂÅè‚ÄùÔºåÊàë‰ª¨ËÆæËÆ°‰∫Ü‰∏Ä‰∏™‚Äú‰∫îÂ±ÇÈò≤Êä§ÁΩë‚ÄùÔºö
1.  ‰ª∑ÂÄºËßÇÂØπÈΩê (Value alignment) ÔºàÁ°Æ‰øùAIÁöÑÊòØÈùûËßÇÂíå‰∫∫Á±ª‰∏ÄËá¥Ôºâ
2.  ÁõÆÊ†áÂØπÈΩê (Goal alignment) ÔºàÁ°Æ‰øùAIÊÉ≥ÂÅöÁöÑÔºåÂ∞±ÊòØÊàë‰ª¨ËÆ©ÂÆÉÂÅöÁöÑÔºâ
3.  ÂèØÈù†ÊÄß (Reliability) ÔºàÁ°Æ‰øùAIÂú®ÂêÑÁßçÊÉÖÂÜµ‰∏ãÈÉΩËÉΩÁ®≥ÂÆöÂ∑•‰ΩúÔºâ
4.  ÂØπÊäóÊÄßÈ≤ÅÊ£íÊÄß (Adversarial robustness) ÔºàÁ°Æ‰øùAI‰∏ç‰ºöË¢´ÊÅ∂ÊÑè‚ÄúÊäïÊØí‚ÄùÊàñÊ¨∫È™óÔºâ
5.  Á≥ªÁªüÂÆâÂÖ® (System safety) ÔºàÁ°Æ‰øùÊï¥‰∏™AIÁ≥ªÁªüÊú¨Ë∫´ÊòØÂÆâÂÖ®ÁöÑÔºå‰∏ç‰ºöË¢´ÈªëÂÆ¢Âà©Áî®Ôºâ

Êàë‰ª¨ÂØπ‰∏Ä‰∏™Âè´‚ÄúÊÄùÁª¥ÈìæÂø†ËØöÂ∫¶‚Äù (Chain-of-thought faithfulness) ÁöÑÂ∑•ÂÖ∑ÁâπÂà´ÂÖ¥Â•ã ÔºàËøôÁé©ÊÑèÂÑøÊòØÁî®Êù•Á°Æ‰øùAI‰∏ç‰ªÖÁªôÂá∫Ê≠£Á°ÆÁ≠îÊ°àÔºåËøòËÉΩËØöÂÆûÂú∞ÂëäËØâÊàë‰ª¨ÂÆÉÊòØÊÄé‰πàÊÉ≥Âá∫Êù•ÁöÑÔºâ„ÄÇ‰∏çËøáÂÆÉÁõÆÂâçËøòÊúâÁÇπ‚ÄúËÑÜ‚Äù ÔºàÂÆπÊòì‚ÄúÁøªËΩ¶‚ÄùÊàñÂ§±ÊïàÔºâÔºåËøòÈúÄË¶ÅÂàíÂÆöÊ∏ÖÊô∞ÁöÑËæπÁïåÂíåÊäΩË±°„ÄÇ

Âú®‰∫ßÂìÅÊñπÈù¢ÔºåÊàë‰ª¨Ê≠£Âä™ÂäõËΩ¨ÂûãÊàê‰∏Ä‰∏™ÁúüÊ≠£ÁöÑ‚ÄúÂπ≥Âè∞‚Äù„ÄÇÊàë‰ª¨Â∏åÊúõÔºåÊú™Êù•ÁªùÂ§ßÈÉ®ÂàÜ‰ª∑ÂÄºÊòØÁî±ÈÇ£‰∫õÂú®Êàë‰ª¨ÊäÄÊúØ‰∏äÔºàÊØîÂ¶ÇÊàë‰ª¨ÁöÑAPIÊàñChatGPTÈáåÁöÑÂ∫îÁî®ÔºâÊêûÂºÄÂèëÁöÑ‰∫∫ÂíåÂÖ¨Âè∏ÂàõÈÄ†ÁöÑ„ÄÇÊàë‰ª¨ÁöÑÁªàÊûÅÁõÆÊ†áÊòØÔºåÊèê‰æõ‰∏Ä‰∏™‚ÄúAI‰∫ë‚ÄùÔºåËÉΩÂÇ¨ÁîüÂá∫Â∑®Êó†Èú∏‰ºÅ‰∏ö„ÄÇ

Á†∏Ëøô‰πàÂ§öÈí±ÔºåÊàë‰ª¨ÂøÉÈáåÊúâÂ∫ïÂêóÔºüÊúâ„ÄÇÂõ†‰∏∫Êàë‰ª¨ÁúãÂà∞‰∫ÜÊ®°ÂûãËÉΩÂäõÂíåÊî∂ÂÖ•Â¢ûÈïøÁöÑÂñú‰∫∫ÂâçÊôØ„ÄÇÊàë‰ª¨ÁîöËá≥ËøòÊÉ≥‚ÄúÊêûÂæóÊõ¥Â§ß‚Äù‚Äî‚ÄîÊàë‰ª¨ÊÉ≥ÈÄ†‰∏Ä‰∏™‚ÄúAIÂ∑•ÂéÇ‚ÄùÔºåËÉΩ‰ª•ÊØîÁé∞Âú®‰ΩéÂæóÂ§öÁöÑÊàêÊú¨ÔºåÊØèÂë®‚ÄúÁîü‰∫ß‚ÄùÂá∫ 1 ÂêâÁì¶ÁöÑÊñ∞Â¢ûÁÆóÂäõ„ÄÇ‰∏çËøáÔºåË¶ÅÂÆûÁé∞Ëøô‰∏™‚ÄúÂ§ßË∑®Ë∂ä‚ÄùÔºåÊàë‰ª¨ËøòÈúÄË¶ÅÂØπÊú™Êù•ÁöÑÊ®°Âûã„ÄÅÊî∂ÂÖ•‰ª•ÂèäÊäÄÊúØÂíåÈáëËûçÂàõÊñ∞ÊúâÊõ¥Â§ßÁöÑ‰ø°ÂøÉÊâçË°å„ÄÇ

legacy.description: AI is cool i guess

result.text:
Yesterday we did a livestream. TL;DR:

We have set internal goals of having an automated AI research intern by September of 2026 running on hundreds of thousands of GPUs, and a true automated AI researcher by March of 2028. We may totally fail at this goal, but given the extraordinary potential impacts we think it is in the public interest to be transparent about this.

We have a safety strategy that relies on 5 layers: Value alignment, Goal alignment, Reliability, Adversarial robustness, and System safety. Chain-of-thought faithfulness is a tool we are particularly excited about, but it somewhat fragile and requires drawing a boundary and a clear abstraction.

On the product side, we are trying to move towards a true platform, where people and companies building on top of our offerings will capture most of the value. Today people can build on our API and apps in ChatGPT; eventually, we want to offer an AI cloud that enables huge businesses.

We have currently committed to about 30 gigawatts of compute, with a total cost of ownership over the years of about $1.4 trillion. We are comfortable with this given what we see on the horizon for model capability growth and revenue growth. We would like to do more‚Äîwe would like to build an AI factory that can make 1 gigawatt per week of new capacity, at a greatly reduced cost relative to today‚Äîbut that will require more confidence in future models, revenue, and technological/financial innovation.

Our new structure is much simpler than our old one. We have a non-profit called OpenAI Foundation that governs a Public Benefit Corporation called OpenAI Group. The foundation initially owns 26% of the PBC, but it can increase with warrants over time if the PBC does super well. The PBC can attract the resources needed to achieve the mission.

Our mission, for both our non-profit and PBC, remains the same: to ensure that artificial general intelligence benefits all of humanity.

The nonprofit is initially committing $25 billion to health and curing disease, and AI resilience (all of the things that could help society have a successful transition to a post-AGI world, including technical safety but also things like economic impact, cyber security, and much more). The nonprofit now has the ability to actually deploy capital relatively quickly, unlike before.

In 2026 we expect that our AI systems may be able to make small new discoveries; in 2028 we could be looking at big ones. This is a really big deal; we think that science, and the institutions that let us widely distribute the fruits of science, are the most important ways that quality of life improves over time.

result.text:
The layoff wave tells two stories, not one.

Tech giants like Amazon, Meta, and Microsoft are cutting to fund GPU purchases. Their revenues are growing. Their stock prices are climbing. They're firing people to free up cash for compute. This isn't cost-cutting during a downturn. It's a forced reallocation from payroll to datacenter capacity. The math is brutal: every percentage point of headcount reduction funds another batch of H100s.

Meanwhile, UPS, Nestle, Ford, and Target are cutting for the opposite reason. They've already deployed AI tools that work. Customer service automation, supply chain optimization, generative design systems. The productivity gains are real and compounding. These companies don't need to buy massive GPU clusters. They're renting inference from hyperscalers and cutting headcount because the math finally works.

Both sides are feeding the same beast. Tech companies are buying the shovels. Everyone else is buying the gold those shovels dig up. Semiconductor companies sit in the middle, collecting rent from the entire value chain. TSMC, NVIDIA, and ASML are printing money while employment craters on both ends.

The timing matters. We're at 10% enterprise AI adoption, heading toward 50%. History says this phase moves fastest and generates the most wealth. But that wealth is concentrating in compute, not labor. The gap between market cap growth and wage growth has never been wider. This isn't a recession. It's a rebalancing. And most workers are on the wrong side of it.

legacy.full_text:
The layoff wave tells two stories, not one.

Tech giants like Amazon, Meta, and Microsoft are cutting to fund GPU purchases. Their revenues are growing. Their stock prices are climbing. They're firing people to free up cash for compute. This isn't cost-cutting during a downturn.

result.text:
Grokipedia correctly distinguishes applied physics from chemistry with its edit, while the Wikipedia article makes a significant academic error and is imprecise

Why: "Chemistry" and "Physics" are distinct, foundational sciences. Applied physics is a branch within physics

The Error: Listing "Chemistry" as a whole under applied physics is a broad categorization error. The specific overlap between the fields is "Chemical Physics," which is already listed separately

Elon Musk came up with a pretty incredible idea during the Q3 Earnings Call, that no one is really talking about. 

His words: ‚ÄúActually, one of the things I thought, if we've got all these cars that maybe are bored, while they're sort of, if they are bored, we could actually have a giant distributed inference fleet and say, if they're not actively driving, let's just have a giant distributed inference fleet.
At some point, if you've got tens of millions of cars in the fleet, or maybe at some point 100 million cars in the fleet, and let's say they had at that point, I don't know, a kilowatt of inference capability, of high-performance inference capability, that's 100 gigawatts of inference distributed with power and cooling taken, with cooling and power conversion taken care of. That seems like a pretty significant asset.‚Äù

So basically, each car has ~1 kilowatt of high-performance AI inference capability, Tesla wouldn‚Äôt need to build giant data centers ‚Äî the fleet is the data center. 

Tesla could turn their entire fleet into a giant distributed inference network, spread across the world, powered by the batteries and AI in the car already.

Mind blown.

‰Ω†ÊúâÊ≤°ÊúâÂèëÁé∞ÔºåÊúÄËøëÊúâÁõ∏ÂΩìÂ§öÁöÑ‰∫∫Âú®Âà∞Â§ÑÂØªÊâæÊäÄÊúØÂêà‰ºô‰∫∫ÊàñËÄÖ CTOÔºü

ÂèçÊ≠£ÊàëÂêßÔºåÊî∂Âà∞‰∫ÜÂ§öÂæóÊÉä‰∫∫ÁöÑËøôÁ±ªÂí®ËØ¢Ôºõ‰ªñ‰ª¨ÁöÑËØùÊúØÂ§ßÂêåÂ∞èÂºÇÔºö‚ÄúÂòøÔºåÊàëËøôÂÑøÊúâ‰∏™‚ÄòÂá≠ÊÑüËßâÁºñÁ®ã (Vibe Coding)‚ÄôÊêûÂá∫Êù•ÁöÑ AppÔºå‰Ω†ÊÑøÊÑèÂ∏ÆÊàëÊääÂÆÉÂÅöÊàê‚ÄòÁîü‰∫ßÂ∞±Áª™‚ÄôÔºà‰πüÂ∞±ÊòØËÉΩÊ≠£Âºè‰∏äÁ∫ø„ÄÅÁ®≥ÂÆöËøêË°åÔºâÁöÑÁâàÊú¨ÂêóÔºü‚Äù

ÊàëÊî∂Âà∞Ëøô‰∫õÊ±ÇÂä©ÔºåËøô‰∏™‰∫ãÂÆûÊú¨Ë∫´Â∞±ËØ¥Êòé‰∫Ü‚ÄúËΩØ‰ª∂Â∑•Á®ã‚ÄùËøô‰∏™Ë°å‰∏öÁöÑ‰∏Ä‰∫õÈóÆÈ¢ò„ÄÇÊàëÁöÑÊÑèÊÄùÊòØÔºåÂ¶ÇÊûúËΩØ‰ª∂Â∑•Á®ãÁúüÁöÑÂ∑≤ÁªèË¢´ AI Ëá™Âä®Âåñ‰∫ÜÔºåÈÇ£Ê†πÊú¨‰∏ç‰ºöÊúâ‰∫∫Êù•ÊâæÊäÄÊúØÂêà‰ºô‰∫∫„ÄÇ

ËøôÊòØÊàëÂú®Ëä±‰∫ÜÂ§ßÈáèÊó∂Èó¥Áî® AI ËæÖÂä©ÁºñÁ®ã„ÄÅÂπ∂‰∏îÁúã‰∫ÜÊó†Êï∞Âà´‰∫∫ÁöÑÊºîÁ§∫‰πãÂêéÔºåÂæóÂá∫ÁöÑÁªìËÆ∫„ÄÇ

result.text:
Summary of the OpenAI livestream "OpenAI Update and Q&A" with Sam Altman, Jakub Pachocki and Wojciech Zaremba (2025-10-28)

Mission and product direction

- Mission across the nonprofit and new PBC is to ensure AGI benefits all of humanity

- Shift from an oracular AGI to tools people use to create the future, with a personal AGI you can use anywhere, with access to services and systems

- Three pillars are research, product, infrastructure, with a stack of chips, racks, data centers, energy, models, OpenAI account, the Atlas browser, and devices in the next few years, plus first party apps like ChatGPT and Sora

- Moving from an AI super assistant in ChatGPT to an AI cloud others build on via API, apps in ChatGPT, and an enterprise platform, with the goal next year that builders create more value than OpenAI

- Platform principles are user freedom and strong privacy protections, including ideas like AI privilege

Research roadmap and timelines

- Deep learning scaled up may be less than a decade away from superintelligence on many critical axes

- Current models handle about a five hour horizon, and match top humans in the International Olympiad in mathematics and informatics

- Progress comes from algorithmic innovation and scaling, including in context compute and test time compute, with willingness to use entire data centers on hard problems

- Targets are an intern level AI research assistant by September 2026, and a fully automated AI researcher by March 2028, with models starting small discoveries in 2026, and medium or larger by 2028

- They have pieces that, when combined, give a realistic shot at a tremendously important step forward within about a year

Safety and alignment

- Five layers are value alignment, goal alignment, reliability, adversarial robustness, systemic safety

- Value alignment covers what the AI cares about, high level principles, and behavior with unclear or conflicting objectives

- Chain of thought faithfulness keeps parts of internal reasoning free from supervision, uses a summarizer in ChatGPT, relies on controlled privacy and clear boundaries, shows promising internal results, and is fragile, so studied carefully

- Labs are sharing safety techniques and standards, with joint investigations on chain of thought faithfulness with researchers from Google and Anthropic, and a call to study together before any recursive self improvement phase

- Product choices aim for long term satisfaction and well being, with a promise to roll back or adjust if a product becomes addictive

Infrastructure and economics

- Commitments total a little over 30 GW of compute, with about 1.4 trillion dollars in obligations over the next many years

- Stargate data centers are under way, with the first site in Abilene, Texas, and the aspiration is an infrastructure factory that creates 1 GW a week, at about 20 billion dollars per GW, over a five year lifecycle

- Partnerships include AMD, Broadcom, Google, Microsoft, Nvidia, Oracle, SoftBank, and others across chips, fabs, data centers, land, and energy, with supply chain innovation and robotics to help build data centers

- The price of a unit of intelligence has fallen about 40x per year, GPT-3 scale runs basically for free on a phone, and GPT-4 level costs have fallen a lot, which supports more free features as demand grows

- Revenue needs to reach hundreds of billions per year over time, with enterprise a huge driver, and consumer too, plus new products, devices, and AI that discovers science

Structure and policy updates with Q&A

- New structure puts the OpenAI Foundation nonprofit in control of OpenAI Group PBC, with about 26 percent equity at launch that can rise via warrants, the same mission binding the PBC, and a goal for the foundation to be the biggest nonprofit ever

- Initial foundation focus is a 25 billion dollar commitment to use AI to help cure disease through data generation and compute grants, plus an AI resilience effort for risks like mental health, bio, and job displacement, aiming for an ecosystem similar to cybersecurity

- User freedom and privacy updates include treating adult users like adults, adult mode planned for December with more permissive creative writing, age verification to allow more control over routing, and no plans to sunset 4o at present

- Atlas for Windows is planned in some number of months, writing models much better than 4.5 are expected soon with 4.5 kept until a big step forward, there is no exact timing on when something will be called GPT-6 since releases and products are less tightly coupled to research now, GPT-5 is the first reasoning flagship, and huge steps in capability are expected within six months, probably sooner

- IPO is the most likely path with no set date, possible open sourcing of old models like the original GPT-4 as museum artifacts, and a focus on releasing useful small models beyond GPT-4 power at tiny scale
